video-config.troubleshootingIntro: If you're having any trouble getting your webcam set up, please feel free to contact the Infant Studies Centre at 604-822-6408 or email us at infants@psych.ubc.ca

video-consent.datause: We are primarily interested in your child's  reactions to the videos and sounds. A research assistant will watch your video to examine where your child is looking on the screen.
video-consent.payment: There are no known risks to participating in studies like ours where your child is accompanied by you and/or a researcher. The procedure used in this study has been shown to be safe. While there are no direct benefits, many families enjoy participating in these activities. After we complete the study, you will be able to access any resulting publications on our website and see what you and your child helped us find out about speech and language development. Our annual newsletter can also be found on our website (https://infantstudies.psych.ubc.ca/). If you provide your e-mail address, we will send you an electronic gift card to Amazon for participating in this study (residents of the U.S. will receive a 5 USD gift card to Amazon.com; residents of Canada will receive a 7 CAD gift card to Amazon.ca).
video-consent.purpose: In this activity, we are interested in understanding whether hearing a cultural tune, either in a language your baby knows or is unfamiliar with, would affect their ability to differentiate between language-specific speech sounds.
video-consent.PIContact: Dr. Janet F. Werker at jwerker@psych.ubc.ca
video-consent.procedures: First, you will provide verbal consent by recording a video following steps 2 through 4 on the right side of this page (please make sure you read the entire consent form before doing so!). During this activity, your child will see and/or hear different speakers either singing or speaking. We are interested in where your child is looking on the screen in response to the sounds that they hear. Your child’s looking behaviour will be video-recorded for subsequent observation by a research assistant.

additional_segments.text: At the end of the study, you will be asked to complete a survey about your child's language exposure, early vocabulary development, and familiarity with music. TODO
additional_segments.title: Language survey

additional_segments.text: Lookit is a U.S. organization and all information gathered from the website is stored on servers based in the U.S. Therefore, your video recordings are subject to U.S. laws, such as the US Patriot Act. This act allows authorities access to the records of internet service providers. If you choose to participate in this study, you understand that your video recording will be stored and accessed in the USA. The security and privacy policy for Lookit can be found at the following link: https://lookit.mit.edu/privacy/.
additional_segments.title: US Patriot Act Disclosure

additional_segments.text: If, upon review of your stored video, a researcher were to observe or hear of an incident involving abuse and/or neglect of a child, please be advised that the researcher must, by law, report this information to the appropriate authorities.
additional_segments.title: Child Protection Disclosure

additional_segments.text: To comply with guidelines from research funders and journal publications, electronic research data in data sheets from this study may be shared publicly. The shared data sheets will not contain information that can be used to identify you or your child. Once this dataset is made publicly available, you will not be able to withdraw your consent to sharing the data.
additional_segments.title: Data sharing

video-consent.research_rights_statement: If you have any concerns or complaints about your rights as a research participant and/or your experiences while participating in this study, contact the Research Participant Complaint Line in the UBC Office of Research Ethics at 604-822-8598 or if long distance e-mail RSIL@ors.ubc.ca or call toll free 1-877-822-8598 (Ethics Project ID: TODO).

blocks.title: Important: your child does not need to be with you until the videos begin. First, let's go over what will happen!
blocks.text: To be eligible for this study, your child must be regularily hearing Cantonese or Mandarin. If your child is not currently being exposed to one of these languages, they may be eligble for an English-only version of this study. If you are interested in learning more, please contact the Infant Studies Centre as infants@psych.ubc.ca .

During this study, your baby will first watch videos of singing faces. Then, there will be a series of speech sounds accompanied by a colourful checkerboard and we will record where he or she chooses to look.
You will have a chance to preview a silent version with closed captioning of the experiment ahead of time. After reading the instructions you’ll start the experiment when you and your baby are ready.
The video section will take about 5 minutes.
After the videos, you will answer a few final questions. Then you're all done!

stimuli.caption: At the begining of the study, there will be a woman singing in either English, Mandarin, or Cantonese. Following this, there will be several trials where infants will hear repeated speech sounds. Here's an example.

blocks.text: During the videos, we'll ask that you hold your child over your shoulder like this, so that you're facing away from the screen.

image.alt: Father holding child looking over his shoulder

blocks.text: The reason we ask this is that your child is learning from you all the time. Even if he or she can't see where you're looking, you may unconsciously shift towards one side or the other and influence your child's attention. We want to make sure we're measuring your child's preferences, not yours!

If you'd like to see an example of a video your child will be shown, you can take a look ahead of time now. It's important that you watch the video without your child, so that the videos will still be new to them.

video-preview.previewButtonText: Preview a video (my child can't see the screen)

listblocks.text: In the experiment, there is a longer familiarization period where the same language sound will be repeated. This is meant to bore your child and we expect that they may not look at the screen the entire time, so don't worry if your child doesn't do so! We are more interested in what they are hearing than what they are seeing, so please just try to keep them facing the screen and they can look if they want to.
If your child gets fussy or you must attend to something else, you may pause the study by pressing the space bar. Please only pause the study if your child is fussy.

To end the study early, you may press Control-X and you should see an 'exit' option pop up. You’ll be prompted to note any technical problems you might be experiencing and to select a privacy level for your videos.
As a reminder, press 'space bar' to pause the study, and press 'control-X' to end the study early.

blocks.text: Please turn the volume up so it's easy to hear but still comfortable.
blocks.title: Test your audio

mediaBlock.warningText: Please try playing the sample audio.

video-quality.title: Final webcam setup
video-quality.introText: We'll be analyzing where your child chooses to look during the videos -- but only if we can tell where that is! Please check each of the following to ensure we're able to use your video

instructionBlocks.text: Make sure the webcam you're using is roughly centered relative to this monitor. This makes it much easier for us to tell whether your child is looking to the left or right!

image.alt: Example images of using centered external webcam on monitor or built-in webcam on laptop.

instructionBlocks.text: Turn off any other monitors connected to your computer, besides the one with the centered webcam. (If there's just one monitor, you're all set!)

image.alt: Example images showing laptop screen turned off if using external monitor and webcam, or external monitor turned off if using built-in webcam and laptop screen.

video-quality.recordingInstructionText: You should be able to see your camera view above. Please create and view a short recording to see how your setup looks. When you're ready to start the experiment, click next. You will have a moment to turn around.

debriefing.text:
You and your baby are helping us to better understand how infants are distinguishing between different languages. Previous research suggests that babies use cues in their cultural environment to “activate” a certain language, and we are interested in whether the cultural cue of music would have an effect on such ability. We really appreciate your help with this investigation!

To thank you for your participation, we will be emailing you an Amazon gift card (residents of the U.S. will receive a 5 USD gift card to Amazon.com; residents of Canada will receive a 7 CAD gift card to Amazon.ca) - this should arrive in your inbox within the next week after we confirm your consent video and check that your child is in the age range for this study. If you don't hear from us by then, feel free to reach out! Each child can only participate once, but if you participate again with another child in the age range, you'll receive one gift card per child.
debriefing.title: Thank you for participating in our study!

exit-survey_cond.generateProperties: function(expData, sequence, child, pastSessions) {var eligible = expData['1-study-procedure']['generatedProperties']['ELIGIBLE']; if (eligible) { return { 'debriefing': {                 'text': 'In this study, we were looking at why babies love cats. Your child actually participated. A real debriefing would be more detailed.', 'title': 'Thank you!' } }; } else { return { 'debriefing': {                 'text': 'In this study, we would have looked at why your child loved cats. Your child did not actually participate though. A real debriefing would make more sense.', 'title': 'Thank you!' } }; }}

enum: My child does not regularily hear Cantonese or Mandarin
langChoice.title: Of the two following langauges, which one is your child most familiar with? If your child is regularly exposed to both with equal frequency, then you may choose either lanaguage.

wrongGrp.title: If your child does not regularily hear Cantonese or Mandrin, then they will not be eligible for this version of the study. Your child may be eligible for a English-only version, if you would like more information on that version of the study, please contact the Infant Studies Centre at infants@psych.ubc.ca

(You'll have a moment to turn around again.)

Your child may be eligble for an English-only version of this study. If you are interested in learning more, please contact the Infant Studies Centre as infants@psych.ubc.ca .

study-procedure.generateProperties: function(expData, sequence, child, pastSessions) {var formData = expData['6-eligibility-survey'].formData; if (formData.langChoice == 'Cantonese') { console.log('eligible'); return { 'whichFrames': 0, 'ELIGIBLE': true } } if (formData.langChoice == 'Mandarin') { console.log('eligible'); return { 'whichFrames': 1, 'ELIGIBLE': true } }else { console.log('ineligible'); return { 'whichFrames': [2],  'ELIGIBLE': true } } }
